• In 2010, ambulance providers' costs per transport ranged from $224 to $2,204, with a median of $429, and Medicare margins ranged from -1% to 2%, with a median of 2%.

* TSA has taken steps to enhance screener training, including developing a new dual-function screener training program, implementing an Online Learning Center, and deploying hands-on training tools.
* TSA has not fully established and deployed a recurrent training program for screeners or supervisors.
* TSA has collected limited information to measure screener performance in detecting threat objects, with covert testing being the primary source of information.
* TSA has implemented several efforts to collect performance data, including doubling the number of covert tests conducted, activating TIP on a wide-scale basis, and implementing the annual recertification program.

* <summary>
* IRS has not established a long-term, desired level-of-telephone-service goal based on taxpayers' needs and costs/benefits, instead annually determining funding and expected service level.
* IRS faces challenges in recruiting, training, retaining, and scheduling customer service representatives, with no active attrition monitoring or competency gap assessment for refresher training.
* IRS evaluations of human capital management practices do not consider the effects on long-term customer service goals or interrelationships among practices.
* </summary>

* DOD is planning to replace the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center (LRMC) and the 86th Medical Group (MDG) clinic in Germany with a new medical center.
* The new medical center will be the only tertiary-level referral hospital for EUCOM, CENTCOM, and AFRICOM theaters of operation.
* DOD conducted a cost-benefit analysis in 2009 that determined consolidating the aging LRMC and 86th MDG clinic into one new facility would be more efficient and cost-effective.
* The replacement medical center will be operated and maintained by the Army, with the Air Force providing clinical services.
* DOD's guidance for planning and acquisition of military health facilities (DOD Instruction 6015.17) was used to determine the facility requirements.
* Army Medical Command developed a report summarizing the projected health care requirements for beneficiaries in the areas served by the proposed medical center.
* The estimated square footage for the replacement medical center is used as the basis for developing overall project cost estimates.
* DOD used beneficiary population data, contingency operations, and changes or expected changes in troop strength known at the time to plan for the proposed replacement medical center.
* The replacement medical center is being sized for peacetime operations but is designed with the flexibility to expand capacity during surges to support contingency operations.
* DOD's cost estimating methodology for the replacement medical center substantially met best practice criteria for overall comprehensiveness, but some costs and assumptions were not included in the individual criteria that make up the comprehensive cost estimating characteristic.

<summary>
* The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) governs the management of hazardous waste, including remediation waste.
* RCRA's requirements can negatively impact cleanups by increasing costs and time, and leading to less aggressive remedies.
* The three most significant requirements under RCRA that create disincentives for cleanup are land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements.
* Land disposal restrictions require waste to be treated to specific standards before being disposed of on land, which can be costly and complex.
* Minimum technological requirements set design and operating specifications for facilities that treat or dispose of hazardous waste, which can also be expensive.
* Permit requirements can add time and costs to cleanups, and facilities may try to avoid triggering the permit requirement.
* EPA has identified RCRA remediation waste as a key area for statutory reform due to the high costs and low environmental benefits.
* EPA proposed a comprehensive rule in 1996 to reform RCRA's requirements for managing remediation waste, but withdrew it in 1997 due to stakeholder disagreements.
* EPA concluded that comprehensive reform of remediation waste management can best be achieved through legislative revision of RCRA.
</summary>

• The Department of Defense (DOD) has a department-wide office, Supply Chain Integration, responsible for developing policies and improving accountability, visibility, and control of critical assets, including Special Rocketry Charges I (SRC I) ammunition.
• The Army procures a majority of the department’s ammunition and provides wholesale storage for other military services at Army depots.
• Army depots ship SRC I ammunition owned by other military services to their respective locations upon request.
• Army depots conduct semiannual physical inventories of all SRC I ammunition as required of all installations storing SRC I ammunition.
• Each military service has entities responsible for the accountability, physical inventory, and transportation of SRC I ammunition.
• DODM 5100.76 sets forth DOD policy on the physical security of sensitive conventional arms, ammunition, and explosives (AA&E), requiring continuous program and policy oversight to ensure protection of AA&E within DOD.
• DOD policy requires SRC I ammunition to have a higher level of protection and security than other conventional ammunition.
• DOD and the military services have policy and guidance on how to account for, safeguard, conduct physical inventories, adjust if necessary, track, and ship SRC I ammunition within and between services and to contractors for repair.
• The military services have several automated information systems for managing accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, including tracking by serial number, production lot number, DOD identification codes, serviceability, reporting location, ownership, quantity, and shipment information.

• The Internet's domain name system (DNS) is crucial for connecting names to numerical addresses, enabling communication between computers.
• The U.S. government, through the Department of Commerce, has been overseeing the privatization of DNS management, with ICANN as the private sector entity responsible for this task.
• The transition process has faced challenges and delays, with ICANN's legitimacy and effectiveness as the private sector manager of the DNS still in question.

* Ginnie Mae's market share and guarantee volume have declined over the past 20 years, but it continues to serve its key public policy goal of providing a strong secondary market outlet for federally insured and guaranteed housing programs.
* Changes in the volume and market share of government-backed housing loans are largely the result of policies and decisions made by Congress and the agencies themselves, and improvements to Ginnie Mae's product line benefit government-backed loan programs by making them more liquid.
* Ginnie Mae faces challenges in adjusting its product mix and policies to address changes in the marketplace while continuing to meet the needs of both borrowers who rely on affordable housing programs and of industry stakeholders such as issuers and investors.
* Ginnie Mae has added a number of new products over the years, has made a serious effort to solicit feedback from its business partners, and has expanded its disclosures for investors, but some changes remain beyond its scope.

• The federal government, led by the Social Security Administration (SSA), is the largest producer, collector, and user of personal information in the United States.
• SSA collects and maintains personal information such as names, dates of birth, addresses, and Social Security Numbers (SSNs) to distinguish individuals and ensure they receive the services or benefits they are entitled to.
• SSA is responsible for issuing SSNs and administering three major income support programs for the elderly, disabled, and their dependents.
• SSA is also the repository of information on individuals’ wages and earnings, which is used in tax administration and reported by individuals on their federal income tax returns.
• SSA adopted its first regulation, known as "Regulation No. 1," in June 1937 to protect the privacy of individuals’ records and include a pledge of confidentiality.
• The enactment of subsequent legislation, such as the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) and the Government in the Sunshine Act, caused SSA to reexamine its disclosure and confidentiality policy.
• SSA's disclosure policy is designed to protect the privacy rights of individuals to the fullest extent possible while permitting the exchange of records required to fulfill its administrative and program responsibilities.
• Over the years, SSA has modified its disclosure policy to comply with about 25 statutes, including the Privacy Act of 1974, which regulates the collection, maintenance, use, and disclosure of personal information that federal agencies maintain in a system of records.
• The Privacy Act requires that agencies inform individuals of the authority for the collection and whether it is mandatory or voluntary, the principal purpose for the collection of information, what the routine uses for the information may be, and what the consequences are of not providing the information.

<summary>
* The Antiterrorism Assistance (ATA) program, authorized in 1983, aims to enhance friendly countries' antiterrorism skills, strengthen bilateral ties, and increase respect for human rights.
* The program provides training and equipment, but lacks clear guidance from the Coordinator for Counterterrorism (S/CT) on how to align assistance with broader U.S. policy goals.
* State has not complied with a congressional mandate to report on U.S. international counterterrorism assistance since 1996.
</summary>

<summary>
* In 1998, VA and DOD began a joint effort to develop a comprehensive, lifelong medical record for each service member and veteran.
* The first initiative, GCPR, aimed to create an electronic interface for accessing patient health information from either agency's health information systems.
* GAO recommended designating a lead entity, establishing clear goals, and following sound project management principles to strengthen the project.
* VA and DOD revised their strategy, named the project FHIE, and achieved one-way data transfer from DOD to VA by 2004.
* The departments began developing an interface, CHDR, to exchange health information between their future health systems (HealtheVet VistA and CHCS II).
* VA and DOD implemented demonstration projects (BHIE and LDSI) to exchange electronic medical information between existing systems.
* CHDR faced management challenges, and the departments acknowledged a delay in meeting a previously established milestone for data exchange.
</summary>

<summary>
* DOD has reversed $592 million of illegal or improper closed account adjustments from fiscal year 2000, but reversing these adjustments has revealed additional accounting errors that will require detailed reviews to correct.
* DOD has agreed to reverse and correct $172 million of illegal or improper closed account adjustments from fiscal year 2001, but the remaining $119 million were adequately documented corrections of errors.
* DOD plans to review an additional $1.1 billion of fiscal year 2001 closed account adjustments and complete all reaudits and corrective actions by September 30, 2004.
* DOD has implemented controls to identify and prevent illegal closed account adjustments, resulting in an 80 percent reduction in closed account adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002.
* However, GAO found $253,212 of illegal closed account adjustments processed through a DFAS Columbus computer terminal that did not properly identify and prevent these types of illegal adjustments.
* GAO recommends that DOD continue to monitor and correct closed account adjustments and that the Secretary of Defense direct the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) to ensure that DFAS Columbus completes its reviews and corrections.
</summary>

• The Department of the Treasury (Treasury) used a specific process to decide to extend the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP), involving coordination with relevant agencies.
• Treasury employed an analytical framework and quantitative indicators to make decisions related to extending TARP.

* <summary>
* The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) describes the desired outcome of an income tax audit as determining the correct taxable income and tax liability of the person or entity under audit.
* IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality, including the scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management of an audit, as well as workpaper preparation.
* Workpapers provide documentation on the scope of the audit and the diligence with which it was completed, supporting the auditor's conclusions and the basis for review by management.
* The primary tool used by IRS to control quality under the nine standards is the review of ongoing audit work, conducted by group managers.
* Our review of IRS audit workpapers found that auditors did not always meet the requirements laid out under the workpaper standard, with problems including discrepancies in tax adjustments and missing or incomplete documents.
* IRS has historically found problems with the quality of its workpapers, with auditors meeting all key elements of the workpaper standard in no more than 72 percent of audits between 1992 and 1997. </summary>

<summary>
• The federal workforce faces mission-critical skills gaps, with over 34% of employees eligible to retire by 2020.
• Agencies struggle with skills gaps due to insufficient staff, lack of appropriate skills, or both.
• Budget pressures, changing work nature, and potential retirements exacerbate these issues.
• The General Schedule (GS) system has not kept pace with evolving government requirements.
• Federal hiring processes need to be applicant-friendly, flexible, and meet policy requirements.
• The pay system rewards length of service rather than individual performance and provides automatic annual increases.
• Performance management systems and dealing with poor performers are long-standing challenges.
• Employee engagement could be improved through additional analysis and sharing of promising practices.
• The federal workforce is more highly educated than the private sector workforce.
• OPM has taken steps to improve human capital management, such as finalizing revisions to its strategic human capital management regulation.
</summary>

* The Department of the Interior (Interior) has provided a retention allowance to one Senior Executive Service (SES) manager at the Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST)—the Principal Deputy Special Trustee.
* From fiscal years 2001 to 2005, the average performance award amounts that SES managers received at OST were generally lower than the average amounts provided to other bureaus and offices within Interior and other federal agencies.
* Interior’s Executive Resources Board (ERB) made the final determination on all performance awards and retention allowances provided to SES managers.
* The Principal Deputy Special Trustee received a retention allowance each year from 1999 to 2005, except for 1999 and 2005, when her compensation was slightly under the total maximum allowable.
* Seven of OST’s SES managers received at least two major awards in 2 years or more from fiscal years 2001 to 2006.
* The average performance award amount for OST’s SES managers was higher than other bureaus and offices within Interior and other federal agencies in fiscal year 2001, but generally lower in fiscal years 2002 through 2005.
* Interior’s ERB approved all major awards provided to OST’s SES managers, considering supporting documentation and recommendations from the Performance Review Board.

<summary>
* The electricity industry consists of generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.
* Traditional electricity networks lacked monitoring, communication, and automation technologies.
* The smart grid vision aims to increase reliability, facilitate renewable energy, and provide real-time energy cost information.
* Smart grid modernization involves installing advanced metering infrastructure and adding "smart" components.
* Benefits of smart grid systems include improved reliability, downward pressure on electricity rates, and better integration of renewable energy.
* Both federal and state governments oversee the electricity industry, with FERC regulating wholesale electricity sales and transmission, and state public utility commissions overseeing local distribution and retail sales.
* NERC, overseen by FERC, develops and enforces mandatory reliability standards for the bulk power system.
* The Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 required NIST and FERC to take actions to support smart grid modernization and cybersecurity.
* Cyber threats to the electricity industry can come from unintentional or intentional sources, including natural disasters, software errors, and malicious actors.
* Multiple entities, including NERC, NIST, FERC, and the Departments of Homeland Security and Energy, have taken steps to secure the electricity grid.
</summary>

• The U.S. Bankruptcy Code provides two main approaches for reorganizing or terminating large financial companies: judicial bankruptcy process and special legal and regulatory resolution regimes.
• Bankruptcy is a federal court procedure that aims to help individuals and businesses eliminate or restructure debts they cannot repay, and help creditors receive some payment in an equitable manner.
• The filing of a bankruptcy petition operates as an automatic stay, stopping most lawsuits, foreclosures, and other collection activities against the debtor.
• Equitable treatment of creditors means all creditors with substantially similar claims are classified similarly and receive the same treatment.
• Business debtors may seek liquidation (Chapter 7) or reorganization (Chapter 11) under the Code.
• Proceedings under Chapters 7 and 11 can be voluntary or involuntary.
• A Chapter 7 proceeding involves a trustee taking over the assets of the debtor's estate, reducing them to cash, and making distributions to creditors subject to the rights of secured creditors.
• A reorganization proceeding under Chapter 11 allows debtors to continue some or all of their operations under court supervision as a way to satisfy creditor claims.
• The debtor typically remains in control of its assets and is called a debtor-in-possession (DIP).
• The Federal Reserve and FDIC have taken certain regulatory actions toward facilitating orderly resolution, including efforts that could contribute to cross-border coordination.

<summary>
* The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are responsible for ensuring the safety of meat, poultry, and certain egg products, and all other foods, respectively.
* Both agencies have taken actions to encourage food processors to voluntarily adopt security measures to prevent deliberate contamination, but they lack comprehensive information on the extent to which these measures are being implemented.
* The agencies believe they generally lack authority to mandate security measures and are concerned about the release of sensitive security information under the Freedom of Information Act.
* The National Academies and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have highlighted the need to enhance security at food-processing facilities.
* The report recommends that the Secretaries of Health and Human Services and Agriculture study their agencies' existing statutes to identify additional authorities needed for regulating security measures at food-processing facilities and provide training for field staff on food security measures.
</summary>

<summary>
* 18F and USDS have provided useful services to federal agencies, with most surveyed project managers satisfied with their work.
* Both organizations have developed outcome-oriented goals and procedures for prioritizing projects, but not all goals are outcome-oriented and performance has not been fully measured.
* 18F has delayed its projected date for full cost recovery and has not established associated performance measures.
* USDS has not developed a quarterly report on the 10 high priority programs, and its policy does not clearly define the relationship between CIOs and digital service teams.
</summary>

• DOD's annual budget submissions include justification for all activities, including those funded through Program Budget Decision 736.
• DOD's accounting systems do not separately identify additional appropriations requested to support GWOT.
• DOD did not explicitly take into account the additional funds provided through its annual appropriations to support GWOT in fiscal year 2004.
• DOD did not explicitly take into account the additional funds provided through its annual appropriations to support GWOT in fiscal year 2005.
• DOD's reported obligations for GWOT may not be complete, reliable, or accurate due to financial management systems with acknowledged weaknesses and lack of systematic processes to ensure accurate data entry.
• DOD and the military services used various authorities to cover gaps between supplemental appropriations and reported obligations for GWOT in fiscal year 2004.
• The Army and Air Force are projected to have gaps between supplemental appropriations and reported obligations for GWOT in fiscal year 2005.
• DOD is not explicitly counting the additional funds provided through its annual appropriations to support GWOT when considering funding for GWOT.
• The Congress should consider directing DOD to provide an explanation of how its supplemental appropriations requests reflect the additional funds that were addressed in Program Budget Decision 736 and which DOD requested and received in its annual appropriations to support GWOT.

* The baby boom generation is aging and will start to retire in large numbers in the coming years, leading to a significant change in the ratio of working-age population to the population age 65 and older.
* The aged dependency ratio, which estimates how many workers will be available to support each retiree, is expected to rise from 21 percent in 2000 to 35 percent by 2030.
* Several factors contribute to the increase in the aged dependency ratio, including the slowing growth of the labor force of younger workers and the growing numbers of older persons.
* Some recent changes in Social Security retirement policy may strengthen incentives for older workers to continue working, such as the elimination of benefits reduction for those who work after normal retirement age and the increase in delayed retirement credits.
* Public and private employers are using various arrangements to retain and extend the careers of older workers, such as rehiring retirees, reduced work schedules, and job-sharing, but these programs are not yet widespread.

<summary>
* The largest interagency contracting vehicle is the Multiple Award Schedule (MAS) program, managed by GSA.
* Federal agencies spent at least $60 billion in fiscal year 2008 through various interagency and enterprisewide contracts.
* Sales under the MAS program have been relatively flat, while obligations under Governmentwide Acquisition Contracts (GWACs) have declined slightly.
* Agencies lack reliable and comprehensive data to effectively manage and oversee interagency and enterprisewide contracts.
* Concerns exist about contract duplication, with vendors offering similar products and services on multiple contract vehicles.
* Limited governmentwide policy is in place for establishing and overseeing Multiple Award Contracts (MACs) and enterprisewide contracts.
* GSA faces challenges in managing the MAS program due to lack of transactional data, limited use of pricing tools, and decentralized management structure.
* OMB and GSA recognize the importance of addressing these problems to minimize duplication and leverage the government's buying power.
* GAO made recommendations to improve data, strengthen policy, and better coordinate agencies' awards of MACs and enterprisewide contracts.
</summary>

• The DATA Act requires federal agencies to report spending data to improve transparency and accountability.
• Agencies have identified challenges in reporting intragovernmental transactions and missing or incorrect ZIP+4 information.
• OMB and Treasury have issued guidance on reporting requirements, but additional clarification is needed.
• Agencies are using short-term solutions to link financial and award data, and some agencies may not fully meet May 2017 reporting requirements.
• OMB and Treasury have established a Data Standards Committee to maintain and update data standards.
• Agencies are required to submit updated implementation plans, including timelines, cost estimates, and risks.
• OMB and Treasury are monitoring agency progress and providing feedback.
• Independent audits and reviews can help validate agencies' progress and inform full implementation of the DATA Act.
• OMB and Treasury have made progress in implementing the DATA Act, but challenges remain.

• The FAA is primarily funded by the Trust Fund, which receives revenues from excise taxes on airline tickets, aviation fuel, and cargo shipments. These revenues are then available for use subject to appropriations.
• The administration's reauthorization proposal suggests changing FAA's financing system to one based more on cost-based charges, with funding for ATO coming primarily from user charges on commercial aircraft and fuel taxes on general aviation aircraft.
• The proposal also includes the creation of an advisory board to make recommendations on fee setting and limited borrowing authority for FAA.

• State child welfare systems face growing caseloads, with foster care population increasing from 276,000 in 1984 to 494,000 in 1995.
• Federal government plays a significant role in financing foster care and sets minimum procedural requirements for the placement process.
• States must make reasonable efforts to prevent or eliminate the need for removing children from their homes and provide services for reunification.
• If reunification is not possible, states must find permanent placement for the child, with a case plan reviewed every 6 months and a permanency hearing held within 18 months.
• Some states have enacted laws or policies to shorten the time between entering foster care and the first permanency hearing to less than 18 months.
• States have implemented various operational and procedural changes to expedite and improve the permanency process, such as concurrent planning and revising court procedures.
• The impact of these initiatives is difficult to assess due to the lack of systematic evaluations and outcome data.
• Successful initiatives require long-term involvement of officials, stakeholder consensus, and sustained resources.

<summary>
* OSC uses ARC for contracting support, including the MPRI organizational assessment.
* ARC and OSC did not follow proper contracting procedures for the MPRI task order.
* OSC officials performed duties normally done by contracting officer's representatives without authorization or training.
* ARC contracting officials did not question or validate OSC's justification for the sole-source order.
* OSC hired an intermittent consultant using 5 U.S.C. § 3109, but did not document price reasonableness.
* OSC employees may face difficulties in addressing prohibited personnel practice allegations against the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel.
* Potential options for OSC employees include external investigation or expanded MSPB appeal rights.
* ARC and OSC agreed with GAO's recommendations to improve contracting procedures.
* GAO made clarifications to the report based on OSC's comments but did not make other suggested changes.
</summary>

<summary>
* VA's mission is to provide medical care, benefits, social support, and memorials to veterans.
* VA has three major components: VBA, VHA, and NCA.
* VA operates an IT infrastructure to support its mission, including 240 information systems, 314,000 desktop computers, and 30,000 laptops.
* VA plans to modernize or replace legacy systems, such as PAID and BDN.
* VA's 6-year strategic plan aims to increase veterans' access to benefits and services, eliminate the disability claims backlog, and end veteran homelessness.
* VA faces IT challenges, including failed modernization of systems and lack of interoperability with DOD.
* VA's CIO is transforming the Office of Information and Technology to improve IT management capabilities.
* VA has not yet provided a detailed plan for modernizing its claims processing system for VA care in the community programs.
</summary>

• The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) was established in 1986 to facilitate legitimate travel of visitors for business or tourism to the United States.
• The program was permanently established in 2000 and has since expanded to include 36 countries.
• To qualify for the VWP, a country must meet certain requirements, including offering reciprocal visa-free travel privileges, having a low refusal rate for visa applications, and issuing machine-readable passports.
• The Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) was implemented in 2008 as a requirement for travelers entering the United States under the VWP.
• ESTA collects passenger data and completes security checks before passengers board a U.S.-bound carrier, reducing the burden on travelers and improving program security.
• DHS has taken steps to minimize the burden associated with ESTA, including reducing the frequency of applications and providing earlier notice of ineligibility.
• However, the Travel Promotion Act of 2009 (TPA) fee collected as part of the ESTA application has been a source of dissatisfaction for many VWP country government and travel industry officials.
• DHS has not fully analyzed the potential risks posed by cases where carriers boarded passengers for VWP travel without verifying that they had ESTA approval.
• DHS conducts biennial reviews of each VWP country to determine whether issues of security, law enforcement, or immigration affect their participation in the program, but has not completed half of the mandated reports in a timely manner.

<summary>
* The General Services Administration (GSA) is responsible for providing telecommunications services to federal agencies through programs like FTS2001.
* GSA is planning the FTS Networx acquisition program to replace existing contracts, including FTS2001, Federal Wireless Telecommunications Service, and FTS Satellite Service contracts.
* The Networx program aims to meet agency needs, obtain best value, encourage competition, respond to the changing marketplace, and provide expanded opportunities for small businesses.
* Networx will consist of two acquisitions: Networx Universal and Networx Select, with Universal providing a full range of services and Select offering leading-edge services.
* GSA faces challenges in finalizing the Networx program strategy, including ensuring adequate inventory information, establishing measures of success, structuring contracts, and planning transitions.
* GSA and federal agencies may lack comprehensive, accurate inventories of existing services, hindering informed acquisition planning.
* GSA has not yet defined a comprehensive set of performance measures for the Networx acquisition program.
</summary>

• **HCFA's Role and Size**: HCFA is the agency responsible for Medicare, serving 33 million beneficiaries and processing 900 million claims annually from various providers. It oversees 400 managed care plans and has 4,000 full-time employees.

• **Medicare Benefits**: Medicare is divided into two parts: Part A (hospital insurance) covering inpatient hospital, skilled nursing, hospice, and home health care services, and Part B (supplementary medical insurance) covering physician and outpatient services, diagnostic tests, and medical supplies.

• **HCFA's Workforce and Contractors**: HCFA has 65% of its employees working at headquarters, with the rest in regional offices. It also oversees 60 claims processing contractors, employing around 22,200 people.

• **Legislative Reforms**: Two recent acts, HIPAA and BBA, grant HCFA substantial authority to reform Medicare, including enhancing anti-fraud activities, expanding health plan choices, and revamping payment systems.

• **HCFA's Challenges**: HCFA faces management challenges such as implementing BBA reforms, preparing for the year 2000, transitioning from lost contractors, and restructuring its organization.

• **Manager Concerns**: Managers expressed concerns about resource distribution, need for specialized expertise, loss of institutional experience, and reorganization issues.

• **HCFA's Reorganization**: In 1997, HCFA restructured its organization to better focus on its mission, combining activities and establishing three components focused on beneficiaries, health plans and providers, and Medicaid.

• **GAO's Work**: GAO is assessing HCFA's efforts to implement HIPAA and BBA, modernize information systems, and monitoring reorganization progress.

* SSA administers two programs (DI and SSI) with the same disability definition, but different eligibility requirements and benefit amounts. DI is linked to work history, while SSI provides a minimum income for those with limited income and assets.
* About 14% of disability beneficiaries receive both DI and SSI benefits (concurrent beneficiaries), who are more likely to have mental impairments and be female, with an average age of 45.

<summary>
* FSA manages and administers student financial assistance programs, providing over $50 billion in aid to 8 million students annually.
* FSA has made progress in improving customer and employee satisfaction, but needs to address systems integration, program integrity, and human capital management.
* FSA's unit cost calculation for administering student aid programs is complex and should be better explained in performance plans and reports.
* FSA should develop clear goals, strategies, and measures to demonstrate progress in integrating financial aid systems and enhancing program integrity.
</summary>

• The U.S. government supported 65 solar-related initiatives across six agencies in fiscal years 2010 and 2011.
• These initiatives focused on research and development (R&D) and commercialization of solar technologies.
• The initiatives supported various types of solar technologies, including photovoltaics, concentrated solar power, and solar hot water.
• They funded a range of technology advancement activities, from basic research to commercialization, with an emphasis on applied research and demonstration activities.
• The initiatives supported several types of funding recipients, including universities, industry, nonprofit organizations, and federal labs and researchers.

<summary>
* DOD's risk assessment process for chemical and biological defense equipment is flawed and unreliable, leading to an inaccurate low risk assessment.
* DOD cannot provide all required ensembles for 682,331 servicemembers due to critical service shortages of one component of the ensemble.
* DOD's inventory management of chemical and biological protective gear is inadequate, contributing to increased risk and inaccurate risk assessment.
* DOD's risk assessment is based on individual equipment items, not ensembles, and combines service data into a consolidated DOD inventory position, obscuring service-specific shortages.
</summary>

• **Transit-Oriented Development (TOD) Definition**: Compact, mixed-use, walkable neighborhoods near transit, typically within a half-mile of a transit station.
• **Factors Supporting TOD**: Demand for real estate, available land for development, supportive local residents, efficient access to jobs and activity centers.
• **Challenges Hindering TOD**: Higher construction costs, lenders' reluctance, lengthy approval processes, unsupportive local population, unattractive development sites.
• **Local Government Policies to Encourage TOD**: Zoning regulations, station area planning, targeted infrastructure investments, tax incentives.
• **FTA's Role in TOD**: FTA considers factors related to TOD when assessing proposed projects, with land use and economic development criteria accounting for one-third of the project rating.
• **Case Studies**: Six transit lines were studied to determine the extent of TOD and factors affecting it, with results not generalizable to all federally funded transit lines.

<summary>
* The Commander's Emergency Response Program (CERP) in Afghanistan focuses on development and construction projects, unlike Iraq where it's mainly reconstruction.
* The program has evolved to include more complex and costly projects, with 129 projects costing over $500,000 in fiscal year 2008 compared to 9 in 2004.
* Management and oversight of CERP is challenging due to an insufficient number of trained personnel and inadequate training.
* Coordination between DOD and USAID on development projects is limited by the lack of a common database for tracking projects.
* The expected surge in troops and funding for Afghanistan highlights the need for adequate training and oversight of CERP personnel.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Social Security Administration (SSA) introduced the Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statement (PEBES) in 1988 to help workers review their earnings records and estimate their future benefits.
* Less than 2% of workers request these statements annually, so SSA plans to send them automatically to eligible workers by fiscal year 2000.
* The PEBES aims to inform workers about available benefits, assist in financial planning, and ensure accurate earnings records.
* The projected cost for fiscal year 2000 is $80 million, including production and personnel costs.
* SSA estimates that 608 staff-years will be required to handle the PEBES workload in fiscal year 2000.
* The benefit estimates provided in the PEBES are based on assumptions about future employment and earnings, and may not reflect certain special circumstances.
* Public reaction to receiving an unsolicited PEBES has been consistently favorable, with 95% of respondents finding the information helpful.
* However, the current PEBES provides too much information and is too complex, potentially overwhelming readers and undermining its usefulness.
</summary>

* **Evaluation Use in Federal Agencies**: Most federal managers reported having access to evaluations, with 40% having recent evaluations. These evaluations contributed to improving program management or performance and assessing program effectiveness.
* **Barriers to Evaluation Use**: The most frequently reported barrier to evaluation use was lack of resources to implement evaluation findings (29%). Other barriers included difficulty distinguishing between program results and other factors (18%), and concern about the relevance of evaluation issues (15%).
* **Facilitators of Evaluation Use**: Agency leadership support for evaluation (38%), staff involvement (35%), and evaluation relevance to decision makers (36%) were the most frequently reported factors facilitating evaluation use.

<summary>
* FAA has authority to authorize UAS operations in the national airspace.
* FAA currently allows UAS access on a case-by-case basis through COAs, experimental certificates, and section 333 exemptions.
* FAA has issued a Notice for Proposed Rulemaking for small UAS operations.
* FAA has designated six UAS test sites for research and testing.
* Foreign countries are also experiencing an increase in UAS use and have begun allowing commercial entities to fly UASs under limited circumstances.
* UAS regulations in other countries require similar safety measures and have some differences in details compared to FAA's proposed rules.
* FAA faces critical steps to keep the UAS integration process moving forward, including issuing a final rule for small UASs and developing an implementation plan.
* Test sites require COAs for operations and need incentives to encourage greater UAS operations.
* FAA and UAS industry stakeholders have begun a public education campaign to promote safe and responsible UAS operations.
* UAS integration into the national airspace system will require addressing air traffic management challenges.
</summary>

• The federal government has appropriated nearly $88 billion for hurricane relief and recovery efforts through four emergency supplemental appropriations acts.
• FEMA received $60 billion for the Disaster Relief Fund, DOD received $1.9 billion, and COE received $400 million in the first two acts.
• FEMA is required to report weekly to the Appropriations Committees on the use of funds it received, but these reports do not provide timely information from a governmentwide perspective.
• FEMA's reported obligations and expenditures for mission assignments do not reflect the status from a governmentwide perspective.
• There is no framework or mechanisms in place to collect and consolidate information, and to report on the $88 billion in hurricane relief and recovery funds provided thus far to 23 federal agencies on a governmentwide basis.
• The government's progress in the rebuilding efforts will be difficult to measure without consistent, reliable, and timely governmentwide information on the use of this funding.
• To improve information on the status of hurricane relief and recovery funds, FEMA should explain in its weekly reports how its reported obligations and expenditures for mission assignments do not reflect the status from a governmentwide perspective, and OMB should establish a framework for governmentwide reporting on the status of hurricane-related funding.

<summary>
* The Rehabilitation Act defines a person with a disability as someone with a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities.
* Federal statutes and regulations provide special hiring authorities for people with disabilities, such as Schedule A and appointments for veterans with disabilities.
* Executive Order 13548 requires federal agencies to take certain actions to increase the employment of individuals with disabilities, such as developing hiring plans and designating a senior-level official.
* OPM reviewed 66 agency plans and found that many did not meet all of its review criteria, such as not including numerical goals for hiring people with disabilities or identifying a senior-level official responsible for the plan.
* OPM is developing mandatory training programs for hiring managers and human resource personnel on the employment of individuals with disabilities, and is assessing the accuracy of SF-256 data on the number of individuals with disabilities in the federal government.
</summary>

• The public faces a high risk of severe disruption to critical services provided by the government and private sector due to the Year 2000 computing crisis, including delayed financial transactions, grounded flights, power loss, and national defense impacts.
• The information and telecommunications sector is particularly vulnerable, as it enables essential services such as electronic fund transfers, manufacturing, and emergency services, and is highly interconnected with other sectors.

<summary>
* As of September 30, 2010, NIH made over 21,500 grant awards using Recovery Act funds.
* NIH used standard review processes and criteria for awarding these grants.
* The grants varied in size, geographic distribution, duration, and research methods.
* The funds had to be obligated within a 2-year window (fiscal years 2009 and 2010).
* OMB guidance requires recipients to report the number of jobs supported by the Recovery Act on a quarterly basis.
* NIH and grantees collect information about FTEs supported by Recovery Act funding from various sources.
* The number of FTEs supported by NIH Recovery Act funds increased from December 2009 to June 2011.
* NIH estimates that Recovery Act funds could eventually support a total of approximately 54,000 FTEs.
* The Star Metrics program is expected to provide additional information about the number and types of jobs funded by the Recovery Act.
* NIH officials reported that the Star Metrics program is an ongoing initiative and is expected to release preliminary results regarding jobs in 2012.
</summary>

• IQA consists of two major elements: guidelines for agencies to ensure quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity of information, and a correction mechanism for affected persons to seek and obtain correction of information.
• OMB issued governmentwide IQA guidelines that agencies used as the basis for developing their own guidelines, including an administrative mechanism for correction requests and appeals.
• Agencies implemented IQA guidelines and correction mechanisms, with some agencies not having guidelines or not posting them online.
• OMB provided assistance and guidance to agencies in developing and implementing IQA, including reviewing guidelines and monitoring correction requests.

• **BLM's Mission**: Manage public lands and resources for the American people, covering about 270 million acres in 28 states and 300 million acres of subsurface mineral resources.
• **ALMRS/Modernization Project**: A mission-critical system to automate land and mineral records and case processing, and provide information for land and resource management.
• **Project Components**: ALMRS IOC (Initial Operating Capability), Geographic Coordinate Data Base (GCDB), and modernization of computer and telecommunications infrastructure.
• **Project History**: Originally estimated at $880 million, scaled down to $575 million, and later reduced to $403 million after contract award.
• **Project Status**: Most milestones met, but some tasks are becoming more complex as development nears completion.
• **Project Challenges**: Tight development and deployment schedules with little recovery time for unexpected problems, and potential cost overruns.
• **Recommendation**: BLM should ensure that the entire ALMRS/Modernization is thoroughly stress tested before deployment to ensure it can process peak workloads.

• IAEA is an independent organization affiliated with the United Nations, responsible for implementing nuclear safeguards.
• The IAEA's governing bodies include the General Conference and the Board of Governors, with the United States being a permanent member.
• IAEA's authority to establish and administer safeguards comes from its statute, the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT), and other treaties.
• The NPT requires non-nuclear weapon states to conclude safeguards agreements with IAEA, while nuclear weapon states have voluntarily accepted safeguards.
• IAEA's safeguards objectives are to account for nuclear material necessary for producing a nuclear weapon and to detect any diversion of this material.
• The agency uses various measures, such as inspections, material accounting, containment, and surveillance devices, to verify that nuclear material is not diverted to nuclear weapons or other proscribed purposes.
• IAEA has taken steps to strengthen safeguards by more aggressively seeking assurances that countries are not pursuing clandestine nuclear programs.
• The Nuclear Suppliers Group (NSG) was established in 1975 to control the export of nuclear materials and equipment.
• The NSG has helped stop, slow, or raise the costs of nuclear proliferation, but faces challenges such as lack of complete export licensing information sharing and voluntary, nonbinding membership.

* Refugees are generally defined as people outside their country due to persecution or fear of persecution.
* The Refugee Act of 1980 provides a systematic procedure for admitting refugees to the U.S.
* Several federal, state, and local agencies coordinate to implement refugee resettlement.
* Refugees are assigned to communities based on an evaluation of the communities' capacity to serve them.
* The federal government provides funding for refugee resettlement services.
* Refugees can benefit communities socially and economically, but may also strain local resources.
* Secondary migration can unexpectedly increase the refugee population in a community.
* The federal government aims to facilitate refugee integration into U.S. communities.
* Studies on refugee integration identify indicators, barriers, and facilitators of integration.
* Two communities have developed formal plans to promote refugee integration.

<summary>
* **Pension Plan Changes**: Over the last decade, large sponsors of defined-benefit (DB) pension plans have made several changes, including revising benefit formulas, converting plans to hybrid designs, and freezing plans. 81% of respondents reported modifying DB plan formulas, with 58% increasing generosity for collective-bargaining employees and 48% decreasing it for nonbargaining employees.
* **Health Benefits**: Health care comprised the single largest benefit cost, representing 15% of base pay. 80% of respondents offered retiree health benefits to at least some future retirees, but 46% reported no longer offering it to new employees.
* **Future Changes**: Most respondents indicated they were not planning to make significant changes to their DB plans between 2007 and 2012. However, 50% of respondents indicated they were likely to add or expand automatic enrollment features to 401(k)-type DC plans.
</summary>

<summary>
* Mutual funds and banks are both financial intermediaries that raise funds from savers and invest them back into the economy.
* Banks primarily invest in loans and government bonds, while mutual funds invest in stocks and bonds.
* The importance of bank loans as a source of finance has been declining, with more companies and households turning to securities markets for funding.
* Securitization, where banks sell loans to financial intermediaries who then sell securities to investors, has further reduced the importance of bank loans.
* The report examines the impact of mutual funds on bank deposits and the movement of money from deposits to mutual funds.
* Data from the Federal Reserve's Flow of Funds Accounts and industry sources were used to assess this impact.
* The report found that mutual funds have attracted significant amounts of money that would have otherwise been placed in bank deposits.
* However, the exact magnitude of this impact is difficult to quantify due to limitations in available data.
* The report estimates that the total impact of mutual funds on deposits may have been sizable but probably less than $700 billion between 1990 and 1994.
* The movement of money from bank deposits to mutual funds should have little if any effect on the total supply of loanable and investable funds available to the economy.
</summary>

• SEC, NASD, and NYSE share information through regular meetings and joint task forces to discuss examination findings, guidance, and industry trends.
• SEC reviews SRO examination modules during on-site inspections and broker-dealer oversight examinations.
• SEC, NASD, and NYSE have jointly developed examination modules for recent changes in laws and rules applicable to broker-dealers.
• SEC, NASD, and NYSE do not typically provide copies of their written examination materials to each other due to potential drawbacks such as compromising supervision and competitive reasons.
• SEC officials believe sharing examination modules could compromise SRO innovation and motivation to improve their methods.
• NASD and NYSE officials disagree with SEC's assertions and believe sharing examination modules would enhance their procedures related to mutual funds.

<summary>
* The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) was established in 1968 to reduce federal disaster costs by providing flood insurance to homeowners and businesses.
* NFIP offers subsidized and full-risk premiums, with subsidized rates covering about 40-45% of the full risk.
* NFIP has mapped flood risks across the country, assigning flood zone designations based on risk levels.
* Despite mitigation efforts, inventories of repetitive loss properties and subsidized premium rates have continued to grow.
* NFIP's borrowing authority was increased to $20.8 billion in response to 2005 hurricane losses.
* GAO identified four public policy goals for evaluating the federal role in natural catastrophe insurance: charging premium rates that fully reflect actual risks, limiting costs to taxpayers, encouraging broad participation, and encouraging private markets to provide natural catastrophe insurance.
* NFIP faces financial and operational challenges, including the need to charge rates that reflect full risk, mitigate repetitive losses, increase participation, and improve management and oversight.
</summary>

<summary>
* The 287(g) program allows state and local law enforcement officers to perform immigration enforcement functions under ICE supervision.
* ICE has not clearly documented the objective of the 287(g) program.
* ICE has not consistently communicated how and under what circumstances 287(g) authority should be used.
* ICE has not defined the nature and extent of supervision required for participating agencies.
* ICE has not specified what data should be collected and how it should be reported by participating agencies.
* ICE has not developed performance measures to track progress towards the program's objective.
* ICE has not documented the objective of the 287(g) program in program-related materials.
* ICE has not defined what program information should be tracked or ensured that program information is being consistently collected and communicated.
* ICE has not developed performance measures to assess the effectiveness of the 287(g) program.
* ICE has not consistently articulated the objective of the 287(g) program in program-related documents.
</summary>

• TVA is an independent federal corporation established to improve the quality of life in the Tennessee River Valley.
• TVA's debt reduction plans include rate increases, limiting operating expense growth, and reducing capital expenditures.
• TVA aims to reduce its debt to $22 billion by 2023, but several factors could affect its ability to meet this goal.
• TVA's unfunded pension liabilities have steadily increased over the past 10 years, and it aims to eliminate a $6 billion shortfall by 2036.
• TVA's unfunded pension liabilities affect its financial health and operations, and it plans to contribute $300 million annually to the pension plan for up to 20 years.
• GAO recommends that TVA better document its debt and pension goals in its performance plans and reports, and work with the TVARS board to ensure full funding of the pension plan.

* FDIC provided $970 million in open bank assistance to First City Bancorporation of Texas in 1988.
* First City banks failed in 1992, resulting in a loss of $600 million to the Bank Insurance Fund.
* FDIC's 1992 resolution estimate differed significantly from the actual sale proceeds of $60 million.
* The First City experience provides lessons relevant to the assistance, closure, and resolution of failing banks.
* FDIC and regulators agreed to consider the lessons to improve their processes.
* GAO's review focused on the processes used by regulators to assist, close, or resolve failing financial institutions.
* The review did not question the bases used by the insurer or regulators in making decisions relative to First City.

• The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) are responsible for improving the nation's public health infrastructure and response to emergencies, including bioterrorism.
• HHS has primary responsibility for coordinating the nation's response to public health emergencies, including bioterrorism, and provides funding to states and local governments to upgrade public health infrastructure and health care systems.
• The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has primary responsibility for nationwide disease surveillance, developing epidemiological and laboratory tools to enhance surveillance of disease, and providing technical and financial support to state infectious disease surveillance, prevention, and control.
• The Food and Drug Administration is responsible for safeguarding the food supply, ensuring that new vaccines and drugs are safe and effective, and conducting research on diagnostic tools and treatment of disease outbreaks.
• The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality is responsible for supporting research designed to improve the outcomes and quality of health care, reduce its costs, address safety and medical errors, and broaden access to effective services, including antibioterrorism research.
• The National Institutes of Health is responsible for conducting medical research in its own laboratories and for supporting the research of nonfederal scientists in universities, medical schools, hospitals, and research institutions throughout the United States and abroad.
• The Health Resources Services Administration is responsible for improving the nation’s health by ensuring equal access to comprehensive, culturally competent, quality health care. Its Bioterrorism Hospital Preparedness program administers cooperative agreements to state and local governments to support hospitals’ efforts toward bioterrorism preparedness and response.

• The Single Audit Act of 1984 was passed to improve oversight and accountability of federal assistance provided to state and local governments.
• The act requires entities receiving $100,000 or more in federal financial assistance to have a single audit conducted for that year.
• The single audit is an organization-wide financial statement audit that includes testing of internal control and compliance with laws and regulations.
• The PCIE report found that 49% of single audits were acceptable, while 51% had deficiencies that raised questions about the reliability of the auditors' reports.
• The PCIE report recommended revising standards, requiring minimum continuing professional education for auditors, and reviewing disciplinary processes to improve single audit quality.

* <summary>
* The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) reduced its workforce by 1,894 FTEs between fiscal years 1993 and 1996, with the Office of Housing accounting for the largest percentage of downsizing.
* HUD refocused its mission, reengineered work processes, and took steps to build and maintain employee skills to maintain performance during downsizing.
* HUD's 2020 Management Reform Plan seeks to consolidate recordkeeping and program activities, focus on assessing the quality of the government housing stock, and curtail waste, fraud, and abuse.
* Customer satisfaction with HUD's performance varied, with some customers expressing dissatisfaction due to major losses of staff with adequate technical expertise.
* </summary>

<summary>
* Medicare is a federal health insurance program for elderly and disabled beneficiaries, covering hospital, skilled nursing, hospice, home health, physician, and outpatient services.
* Claims are processed by 49 intermediaries (hospitals and institutions) and carriers (physicians and outpatient services).
* Medicare deviates from standard federal contracting rules, using nomination by provider associations for intermediaries and a small pool of insurers for carriers.
* Medicare uses cost-based reimbursement contracts without explicit provision for profit and has limited termination options.
* Medicare could benefit from competitive bidding, specialization, performance-based contracts, and efficient termination.
* The number of insurers willing to serve as Medicare contractors has declined, while other entities capable of handling claims administration have increased.
* CMS has proposed legislative changes to repeal provider nomination authority and allow contracting with non-insurer entities.
* Functional contracting (separate contractors for specific tasks) and performance-based contracting could improve program management.
* Implementing changes would require careful planning, clear statements of work, evaluation criteria, and coordination among contractors, providers, and CMS staff.
</summary>

<summary>
* IRS designed NRP to obtain new information about taxpayers’ compliance with tax laws.
* NRP focuses on voluntary filing, reporting, and payment compliance.
* NRP’s primary goals are to obtain accurate information and minimize burden on taxpayers.
* NRP consists of casebuilding, classification, and taxpayer audits limited to unverifiable items.
* IRS has made significant progress in casebuilding, classification, and audits.
* NRP includes quality assurance measures to ensure accurate data.
* IRS is surveying taxpayers to assess burden and satisfaction with NRP audits.
* NRP sample size is smaller than initially estimated, and more face-to-face audits are expected.
* IRS continues to work with stakeholders to minimize burden on taxpayers.
</summary>

• The Privacy Act of 1974 and the E-Government Act of 2002 are the major laws governing the protection of personal privacy by federal agencies in the U.S.
• The Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 (FISMA) addresses the protection of personal information in federal agency information systems.

• The Military Health Services System (MHSS) spends over $15 billion annually, with its main mission being medical readiness.
• The MHSS provides medical support to active-duty military personnel and maintains their health during peacetime.
• Psychiatrists and clinical psychologists play a role in meeting the MHSS medical readiness mission by providing mental health care.
• The MHSS created the Prescribing Drug Program (PDP) to increase the scope of practice of clinical psychologists, allowing them to prescribe psychotropic medication under certain circumstances.
• The MHSS has no current or upcoming need for clinical psychologists who may prescribe medication, as it has more psychiatrists than needed to meet medical readiness requirements.

• The U.S. Census Bureau (Bureau) is responsible for planning the 2010 Census, including the American Community Survey (ACS) and the Master Address File/Topologically Integrated Geographic Encoding and Referencing (MAF/TIGER) enhancements.
• The Bureau's Decennial Management Division has been given the responsibility for this task and has established an executive steering committee for this purpose.
• The division has chartered various research and development planning groups to study specific activities related to the 2010 Census.
• The General Accounting Office (GAO) is an independent, nonpartisan agency that works to support Congress in meeting its constitutional responsibilities and to help improve the performance and accountability of the federal government for the American people.
• GAO examines the use of public funds, evaluates federal programs and policies, and provides analyses, recommendations, and other assistance to help Congress make informed oversight, policy, and funding decisions.

<summary>
* DOD focused on reducing support operations and infrastructure costs to increase modernization investments without increasing overall defense budgets.
* DSB estimated that DOD could save $7-12 billion annually by 2002 through aggressive outsourcing of support services.
* DSB's second report proposed a new vision where DOD only provides warfighting, direct battlefield support, policy-making, and oversight activities, with all other activities outsourced to the private sector.
* DSB estimated that DOD could save $30 billion annually by 2002 through this approach, with $6 billion coming from CONUS logistics infrastructure activities.
* PA&E reviewed DSB's estimates and found that the $6 billion in annual logistics savings was overstated by $1 billion and that another $3 billion would be difficult to achieve.
* DSB overstated inventory management savings and assumed a higher savings rate from outsourcing than was realistic.
* DSB's estimate of annual savings from equipment reliability improvements was overstated by at least $1.2 billion.
* Legal and cultural impediments may reduce DSB's projected savings.
* DOD's effort to reduce costs and achieve savings is important, and it should develop a realistic and achievable cost-reduction program.
* GAO recommends that DOD develop a detailed implementation plan for improving the efficiency and effectiveness of its logistics infrastructure.
</summary>

• Chemical facilities are attractive targets for terrorists due to the potential damage they can cause.
• EPA regulates around 15,000 facilities under the Clean Air Act, but there's no comprehensive assessment of their security.
• DHS is developing a plan to protect the chemical sector, focusing on high-priority facilities.
• Industry associations have taken voluntary measures to improve security, but the extent of participation is unclear.
• Challenges in preparing facilities against terrorist attacks include cost, lack of guidance, and limited threat information.
• DHS lacks specific authority to require all high-risk facilities to assess vulnerabilities and take corrective actions.
• Legislation has been introduced in Congress to give DHS greater authority over chemical facility security.

* The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) project has experienced significant technical challenges that have impacted its ability to meet schedule commitments.
* The project has used a significant portion of its schedule reserve to address these challenges, and is currently on schedule with 8.75 months of reserve remaining.
* The project's cost status is currently within its allocated budget, but the cryocooler development has used a significant share of the project's fiscal year 2015 cost reserves.
* The project's workforce levels have been larger than planned, and the primary contractor, Northrop Grumman, has exceeded its workforce projections for the past 20 months.
* Independent oversight has provided insight into project risks, and the project has benefited from recommendations made by external experts and review panels.

• HHS is responsible for protecting the privacy and security of Medicare beneficiaries' protected health information (PHI), including prescription drug use data.
• Electronic prescribing is a technology used to transmit prescription information between healthcare providers and pharmacies, which involves the use of PHI.
• HIPAA and the HITECH Act establish standards for the use and disclosure of PHI, including requirements for de-identification and breach notification.
• OCR, the HHS office responsible for enforcing HIPAA and HITECH Act requirements, has not yet issued required guidance on de-identification methods.
• OCR has initiated a pilot audit program to ensure covered entities and business associates are complying with HIPAA and HITECH Act requirements, but plans for a sustained audit capability are still under development.
• GAO recommends that HHS direct OCR to issue guidance on properly implementing HIPAA de-identification requirements and establish plans for conducting periodic audits.
• HHS agreed with GAO's recommendations but provided qualifying comments, noting that covered entities have been operating under existing de-identification standards for nearly a decade and that OCR's enforcement activities already ensure compliance with HIPAA rules.

• The Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) was enacted in response to the 2008 financial crisis to stabilize the U.S. economy.
• TARP provided financial assistance to various sectors, including banks, automakers, and homeowners.
• The program had several components, including the Capital Purchase Program (CPP), the Automotive Industry Financing Program (AIFP), the Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility (TALF), and the Public-Private Investment Program (PPIP).
• TARP also funded housing programs, such as the Making Home Affordable (MHA) program, the Hardest Hit Fund, and the FHA Short Refinance program.

<summary>
* The FAA's Air Traffic Control (ATC) system must operate continuously and is responsible for operating a common ATC system.
* FAA's modernization projects have experienced substantial cost overruns, lengthy schedule delays, and significant performance shortfalls.
* Two key components of the modernization effort, the Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS) and the Standard Terminal Automation Replacement System (STARS), have encountered delays and cost increases.
* FAA faces challenges in implementing solutions to the root causes of past problems, ensuring effective acquisition management, and addressing the looming crisis with the year 2000 date requirements.
</summary>

• Social Security is a large federal program providing benefits to retirees, disabled workers, and dependents.
• The program faces long-term financial challenges due to demographic changes and increasing life expectancy.
• Reform proposals often include benefit reductions, revenue increases, or structural changes like individual accounts.
• Benefit reductions could disproportionately affect disabled workers and dependents who may not be able to adjust.
• The report analyzes the effects of six reform elements on disabled workers and dependents.
• These elements include longevity indexing, price indexing, progressive price indexing, increasing computation years, reducing the COLA, and raising the full retirement age.
• The report also examines protections for vulnerable beneficiaries, such as full or partial exemptions, super COLA, and caregiver credits.
• The report finds that most reform elements would reduce median lifetime benefits for disabled workers and dependents.
• The report suggests that Congress should consider the potential implications of reform on disability and dependent beneficiaries when reviewing modernization of the Social Security disability program.

• The Foundation received $3 million from the U.S. Treasury in 1993 for the Memorial Garden project, with an additional $73,152 in interest earned by June 30, 1994.
• The Foundation's financial condition is precarious, with liabilities exceeding assets, and there are doubts about its ability to continue operations and fund future costs of the Memorial Garden.

• Pension plans invest in hedge funds and private equity funds to achieve potential benefits such as higher returns and diversification, but these investments also pose risks and challenges.
• Pension plans take steps to address these risks and challenges, such as conducting due diligence, negotiating investment terms, and investing through funds of funds.

<summary>
• The U.S. provided $970 million in rule of law programs worldwide from 1993 to 1998.
• Annual funding increased from $128 million to $218 million, with a possible dip in 1996 due to data issues.
• Latin America and the Caribbean received the largest share (36%), followed by Africa, Central Europe, and the former Soviet Union (15% each).
• Funding shifted from Latin America and the Caribbean to Central Europe, with Central Europe's share growing from 4% to 31%.
• Latin America and the Caribbean's share declined from 44% to 19%, and Africa's from 30% to 13%.
• Detailed data is available in Appendix I.
</summary>

• Coal-fueled electricity generating units provide a significant share of electricity in the U.S.
• Four key EPA regulations will affect coal-fueled units, with different compliance deadlines.
• EPA projects significant health and environmental benefits from these regulations.
• A new regulation to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from existing fossil-fueled units is proposed.
• DOE, FERC, EPA, and state regulators have roles in overseeing power companies' responses to regulations.
• DOE, EPA, and FERC have taken initial steps to monitor industry progress and coordinate efforts.
• RTOs provide information to agencies on retirements, retrofits, and reliability assessments.
• Power companies plan to retire more coal-fueled capacity and retrofit less than previously estimated.
• Retirements are expected to be concentrated in certain states and among older, smaller, and more polluting units.
• Continued monitoring and coordination by federal agencies and stakeholders are crucial for reliability and price impacts.

• The U.S. territories of American Samoa, CNMI, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands have unique Medicaid and CHIP programs with different eligibility, benefits, and funding structures compared to states.
• Despite their smaller programs and limited resources, territories face challenges in ensuring program integrity and protecting Medicaid and CHIP funds from fraud, waste, and abuse, with limited federal oversight and assistance from CMS.

• Federal officials and stakeholders identified factors that enhance or hinder federal-nonfederal collaboration to reduce wildland fire risk to communities.
• These factors include federal authorities, state and local authorities, initiatives, joint planning, agency resources for collaboration, leadership, education, wildfire prevention messaging, and community engagement.
• Federal officials and stakeholders also identified actions that could improve their ability to reduce wildland fire risk to communities, including improving implementation of the Cohesive Strategy, increasing collaborative planning, expanding education, increasing prevention efforts, improving timber-processing capability, adopting state and local ordinances, and providing insurance incentives.
• The report is not generalizable to all land management units and communities, but provides illustrative examples from a geographically diverse range of land management units and communities at high risk of experiencing wildland fire.

• Franchise funds are government-run, self-supporting businesslike enterprises managed by federal employees.
• They provide a variety of common administrative services, such as payroll processing, information technology support, employee assistance programs, public relations, and contracting.
• Franchise funds are required to recover their full costs of doing business and are allowed to retain up to 4 percent of their total annual income.
• To cover their costs, franchise funds charge fees for services.
• The Government Management Reform Act of 1994 authorized the Office of Management and Budget to designate six federal agencies to establish the franchise fund pilot program.
• Congress anticipated that the franchise funds would be able to provide common administrative services more efficiently than federal agencies’ own personnel.
• The original operating principles for franchise funds included offering services on a fully competitive basis, using a comprehensive set of performance measures to assess the quality of franchise fund services, and establishing cost and performance benchmarks against their competitors.

<summary>
• FSA field offices do not consistently determine the eligibility of estates kept open for more than 2 years, as required.
• Only 39 out of 181 reviewed estates received annual eligibility determinations for each year they were kept open beyond the initial 2 years.
• 73 estates (40%) did not receive any eligibility determinations from 1999 to 2005, with some estates open and receiving payments for over 10 years.
• Some estates received millions in farm program payments without any eligibility determinations, including one open since 1973.
• Even when FSA conducted eligibility determinations, there were shortcomings, such as approving payments with insufficient information or explanation.
• The extent to which FSA field offices make eligibility determinations varies from state to state.
• FSA's lack of management controls resulted in improper payments to deceased individuals, totaling $1.1 billion from 1999 to 2005.
• Payments to deceased individuals through entities accounted for 58% of the $1.1 billion in payments made to all deceased individuals.
• GAO recommended that USDA conduct all required annual estate eligibility determinations, implement management controls to verify that an individual receiving program payments has not died, and recover improper payments.
</summary>

* OPM's retirement modernization initiative, RetireEZ, aims to provide prompt and complete benefit payments upon retirement.
* The program has partially implemented two of eight planned capabilities, while six remain unimplemented.
* OPM has managerial weaknesses in cost estimating, earned value management, requirements management, testing, and program oversight.
* The agency is restructuring the program without a complete plan and has not yet established results-oriented goals and measures.

<summary>
* The U.S. Department of State (State) manages the visa process for foreign nationals seeking to enter the United States temporarily.
* State has implemented new policies and procedures since the 9/11 terrorist attacks to strengthen the security of the visa process, which has added to the complexity of consular workload and increased the time needed to adjudicate a visa.
* State has not developed a strategy for addressing increasing visa demand that balances available resources, national security, and the need for visas to be processed in a reasonable amount of time.
* State has not analyzed the 5-, 10-, or 20-year future staffing and other resource needs based on demand projections, and some projections have already been proven to underestimate growth in demand.
* State should develop a strategy to address worldwide increases in visa demand that balances the security responsibility of protecting the United States from potential terrorists and individuals who would harm U.S. interests with the need to facilitate legitimate travel to the United States.
</summary>

* The U.S. Coast Guard is a multimission maritime military service within the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), organized into two major commands for mission execution and divided into 9 districts and 35 sectors.
* The Coast Guard has responsibilities that fall under two broad missions—homeland security and non-homeland security, further divided into 11 programs with performance measures to communicate agency performance.
* The Coast Guard's budget request for fiscal year 2008 is $8.73 billion, with homeland security missions representing approximately 35% of the overall budget.

* The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), also known as Superfund, established a program to clean up highly contaminated hazardous waste sites.
* EPA administers the Superfund program, oversees cleanups performed by responsible parties, and performs cleanups itself.
* States may enter into contracts or cooperative agreements with EPA to carry out certain Superfund actions, including evaluating sites, cleaning them up, and overseeing the cleanups.
* CERCLA requires EPA to develop and maintain a list of hazardous sites, known as the National Priorities List (NPL), that the agency considers to present the most serious threats to human health and the environment.
* EPA has investigated over 40,000 potential hazardous waste sites and made final decisions about whether or not to include almost 35,000 sites on the NPL.
* EPA has removed waste or taken other interim cleanup actions at over 5,500 sites to address the most urgent risks and stabilize conditions to prevent further releases of contamination.
